title: 12 Beauty Stars Who Are Immigrants
text: Celebrity 12 Beauty Stars Who Are Immigrants We're on the edge of our seats waiting to hear the appeals court's final decision on Trump's proposed immigration ban , and we at Allure keep coming back to the question: What is "American beauty"? It's from Romania and Cuba, from Somalia and Iran. So many of the most revolutionary products, exciting trends, and creative movements in our country's beauty scene have been pioneered by women and men born outside of its borders. This seems like a pretty damn good week to celebrate them. Their numbers are legion, but here are 12 standouts. Anastasia Soare Birth country: Romania Beauty impact: Before Soare, brows were an almost nonexistent category in the beauty business. Anastasia Beverly Hills now has brow salons around the country and a 400-SKU makeup line carried in Sephora, Nordstrom, Macys, and Ulta. Her Dipbrow Pomade and liquid lipsticks are the stuff of legend. Learn more about Soare here . Courtesy of Nick Barose Nick Barose Birth country: Thailand Beauty impact: Barose is a New York–based makeup artist who began his career in America as an assistant to Kevyn Aucoin . His clients now include Lupita Nyong'o , Tracee Ellis Ross, and Gugu Mbatha-Raw . Learn more about his journey here . Courtesy of Adir Abergel Adir Abergel Birth country: Israel Beauty impact: Celebrity hairstylist Abergel creates styles that are never fussy but always have a wow factor. He preps stars like Rooney Mara , Marion Cotillard, and Gwyneth Paltrow for the red carpet and recently launched a line of hair accessories with Lelet New York designer Sara Bieler Sasson. Courtesy of Evan Sung Haideh Hirmand Birth country: Iran Beauty impact: Hirmand is a clinical assistant professor of surgery at Weill-Cornell Medical College and founder of Haideh Hirmand, MD Aesthetic Plastic Surgery and SkinLabRx Regenerative Medispa in New York City. She is known as a specialist in eye and facial rejuvenation and has pioneered safe eye correction techniques. She teaches surgical and injection techniques across the country, and works with the Women for Women Plastic Surgery Aid program, which provides services by female surgeons for female patients in developing countries. Courtesy of Hung Vanngo Hung Vanngo Birth country: Vietnam Beauty impact: Glowy, ethereal, sultry, seamless—all adjectives that have been used a million times (give or take) to describe Vanngo’s work. The makeup artist is as known for giving the Selena Gomez ’s and Julianne Moores’ of the world striking red carpet looks as he is for making just about every Victoria’s Secret angel glisten and gleam . Courtesy of Jin Soon Choi Jin Soon Choi Birth country: Korea Beauty impact: Manicurist Choi is a backstage regular who zips through MoMA for inspiration before turning models’ nails into mini works of art . She collaborates with designers like Marc Jacobs, fashion photographers like Steven Meisel, and magazines like Allure . And if you love nail polish, you probably own at least one—or, more likely, 10—shades from her well-edited line, Jin Soon. But before Choi gave us the best pinky-beige around ( Nostalgia ) or owned three Manhattan salons, she came to New York City with $400 in her pocket. Courtesy of Ouidad Ouidad Birth country: Lebanon Beauty impact: The founder of the curly-hair empire Ouidad pioneered the market for curl-specific hair products . She now has three flagship salons, over 1,000 Ouidad-certified stylists around the country, and more than one Best of Beauty Award . Getty Images Iman Birth country: Somalia Beauty impact: Where do we begin? The very short story: After being discovered by photographer Peter Beard in Nairobi, Iman was one of the most sought-after models on the planet in the ‘70s and ‘80s. She challenged prevailing notions of beauty and became a muse to designers like Halston and Yves Saint Laurent. In 1994, long frustrated that no foundation matched her skin tone, she started Iman Cosmetics , a line for women of color. Getty Images Salma Hayek Birth country: Mexico Beauty impact: In addition to being just an insanely gorgeous human, Hayek created a hair, skin, and makeup line in 2011. Nuance Salma Hayek uses proven ingredients in luxurious formulas—and nothing is over $30. The Buriti Oil Nourishing Shampoo andare Best of Beauty winners. Courtesy of Sylvie Chantecaille Sylvie Chantecaille Birth country: France Beauty impact: Chantecaille started her first cosmetics line with Diane von Furstenberg in the ‘70s. She went on to launch Prescriptives—a pioneer in custom-blending foundation and creator of the Calyx scent (if you were alive in the ‘80s, you wore it). Her third act: Chantecaille, a makeup, skin care and fragrance line that marries her passions for technology and botanicals—and donates proceeds from many of its products to support endangered species around the world, from honey bees to elephants. Courtesy of Negin Zand Negin Zand Birth country: Iran Beauty impact: Now at Benjamin with Negin Zand salon in Los Angeles, Zand has transformed the hair colors of Cate Blanchett, Scarlett Johansson, and Angelina Jolie and dozens of other A-listers. She specializes in natural (and speedy) hand-painted highlights , and has made Allure ’s Best of Beauty Directory 14 times (and counting). Her talent is a family affair: Before Zand’s family left Iran, in the mid-70s, her mother was a very high-profile hairdresser there. “She was the Sally Hershberger of prerevolutionary Iran,” Zand once told Allure . Getty Images Oribe Birth country: Cuba Beauty impact: He’s the single-named hairstylist who defined the '90s with a client roster—Cindy Crawford, Claudia Schiffer, Naomi Campbell—right out of a George Michael video. In 1999, he got a call from Jennifer Lopez and did the hair for the cover of her first album. The two worked together for years. He’s actually credited Lopez as the inspiration for the much-obsessed-over jasmine-and-sandalwood scent of his products. Oribe’s line has many standouts but his Dry Texturizing Spray has inspired praise from more celebrities, hairstylists, blogger, and fashion designers than we can count.
